title: 112_s3531
content: Expansion of credit for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase the credit percentage for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property to 50 percent. There is no dollar limitation for property related to hydrogen. The credit is also allowable for refueling property for certain motor vehicles designed for carrying or towing loads, with a focus on hydrogen fuel storage or dispensing. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase the credit percentage for hydrogen-related alternative fuel vehicle refueling property to 50 percent. The reference to motor vehicles in section 179A(d)(3)(A) now includes specified off-highway vehicles, defined as vehicles propelled by motor designed for carrying or towing loads, excluding farm tractors and trench diggers. The amendment extends the credit for hydrogen property through 2016 and applies to property placed in service after the enactment date for taxable years ending after that date. The amendment excludes certain equipment and vehicles from the definition of hydrogen property. The amendment extends the credit for hydrogen property through 2016 and applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2014. Increased investment credit for more efficient fuel cells. Increased investment credit for more efficient fuel cells, with a 50 percent credit for qualified fuel cell property in a combined heat and power system with an energy efficiency of 70 percent or more, and a 40 percent credit for systems with an energy efficiency of at least 60 percent but less than 70 percent. Increased investment credit for qualified fuel cell property is amended to limit the credit to $2,500 for each 0.5 kilowatt of capacity for property placed in service during the taxable year. The investment credit for qualified fuel cell property is amended to limit the credit to $2,500 for each 0.5 kilowatt of capacity for different types of properties. The amendments will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act.
